channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Syria unrest 'has killed 60,000'
item.description: More than 60,000 people have died since March 2011 in Syria, a sharp jump on other estimates, says the UN human rights commissioner.

item.title: Jim Davidson bailed in abuse inquiry
item.description: Comedian Jim Davidson is one of two men arrested and bailed by police investigating allegations of sexual offences.

item.title: Man held over Thai beach shooting
item.description: Thai police arrest a man over the fatal shooting of a 22-year-old British tourist on New Year's Eve, as the victim's family say they are "completely devastated".

item.title: Markets rally on US fiscal deal
item.description: Global stock markets rally after a short-term deal to stave off the US "fiscal cliff" was reached, averting spending cuts and tax increases worth $600bn (£370bn).

item.title: Malala father given consulate job
item.description: The father of Malala Yousafzai, who was treated in Birmingham after being shot by the Taliban, is given a job in the city.

item.title: Officer shot 'tackling gunman'
item.description: A navy officer was shot in the head as he tried to stop a junior rating killing others onboard a submarine, an inquest hears.

item.title: Winter vomiting cases at 1.1 million
item.description: Cases of the winter vomiting bug norovirus have exceeded 1.1 million, figures for England and Wales suggest.

item.title: Battle over plan to cap benefits
item.description: The government says it is unfair for benefits to rise at a faster rate than wages, but Labour opposes plans to cap rises to 1%, ahead of a key Commons vote.

item.title: Rail travellers hit by fare rises
item.description: Above-inflation rail fare increases have come into force in England, Wales and Scotland amid claims that fares are going up three times faster than average earnings.

item.title: Ground-breaking OLED TV on sale
item.description: The first large OLED television, which promises higher image quality than LCD sets, goes on sale in South Korea.

item.title: Hilary Mantel wins Costa novel prize
item.description: Hilary Mantel wins 2012 Costa novel prize for Bring Up The Bodies.

item.title: US singer Patti Page dies aged 85
item.description: American singer Patti Page, one of the most popular artists of the 1950s with hits including Tennessee Waltz, dies at the age of 85.

item.title: Seal 'swims 50 miles into lake'
item.description: A seal is filmed in a lake at a nature reserve after apparently swimming more than 50 miles up a flooded river.

item.title: Author offers role to dog rescuer
item.description: US author Dennis Lehane, who wrote Shutter Island and Mystic River, pledges to name a new character after the person who returns his missing pet dog.

item.title: Chelsea 0-1 QPR
item.description: QPR snatch a stunning victory over Chelsea at Stamford Bridge through a late Shaun Wright-Phillips strike.

item.title: Liverpool 3-0 Sunderland
item.description: Luis Suarez takes his Premier League tally to 15 goals for the season as Liverpool defeat Sunderland.

item.title: Newcastle 1-2 Everton
item.description: Substitute Victor Anichebe scores within 90 seconds of coming on to give Everton victory at Newcastle United.

item.title: Cole is set for move to West Ham
item.description: Liverpool midfielder Joe Cole is on the verge of joining former club West Ham in a permanent deal.

item.title: Ping pong goes 'rock 'n' roll'
item.description: Sandpaper, pimples, entrance music and orange balls. Table tennis gets the Barry Hearn treatment.

item.title: Avis buys car sharing firm Zipcar
item.description: Global car hire group Avis Budget is to get into the fast-growing car sharing market by buying Zipcar for $500m.

item.title: John Lewis' Christmas sales jump
item.description: The department store chain John Lewis said its sales in the five weeks to the end of December rose by 13%, with both stores and online doing well.

item.title: PM urges 'brave' preparations for G8
item.description: David Cameron tells fellow G8 leaders they must plan now to take "bold steps" at June's meeting.

item.title: Call for US-style 'local shop day'
item.description: The UK should emulate the US idea of having a day dedicated to encouraging people to shop at small, local shops, Labour's Chuka Umunna says.

item.title: Booze calories 'too often ignored'
item.description: People watching their weight should pay closer attention to how much alcohol they drink because of its calorie content, say experts.

item.title: 'Weight is healthy' study criticised
item.description: A study which suggests being overweight can lead to a longer life has caused controversy among obesity experts.

item.title: Teacher morale 'dangerously low'
item.description: Morale among teachers in England and Wales is "dangerously low" and "has declined dramatically in recent months" a teachers' union survey suggests.

item.title: Young 'cannot cope with daily life'
item.description: One in 10 young people feel unable to cope with day-to-day life, according to the Prince's Trust's latest youth index.

item.title: Ubuntu system comes to smartphones
item.description: The Linux-based Ubuntu operating system is to work on smartphones, allowing users to run full-scale programs on handsets designed for Android.

item.title: Paris Apple store hit by heist
item.description: Up to one million euros worth of Apple products has been stolen from a central Paris Apple store.

item.title: Deer numbers changing woodlands
item.description: The increasing abundance of native roe deer appears to be having an impact on woodlands, a study suggests.

item.title: Arctic rig salvage effort delayed
item.description: Attempts to rescue a Shell drill rig grounded off the Alaskan coast are delayed because of high seas and strong winds.

item.title: Womack reveals Alzheimer's fears
item.description: Soul veteran Bobby Womack speaks about having early signs of Alzheimer's disease, meaning he has trouble remembering songs and names.

item.title: UK album sales suffer 11.2% drop
item.description: Overall UK album sales fall by 11.2% in 2012, according to the BPI, although digital album sales rise.

item.title: Been and Gone: War veteran actor and other losses
item.description: Our regular column covering the passing of significant - but lesser-reported - people of the past month.

item.title: Why do innocent people confess to crimes?
item.description: Japan can boast one of the world's lowest crime rates, but in recent months there has been a public outcry over a number of cases where innocent people confessed to crimes they didn't commit.

item.title: Man dies in car at level crossing
item.description: A man dies after a car is struck by a freight train at a level crossing in Oxfordshire.

item.title: Two brothers killed in collision
item.description: Two men killed in a head-on collision in Northamptonshire were brothers, police reveal.

item.title: Driver sought after fatal crash
item.description: A 34-year-old man has died after the car he was in left the road and struck a tree in West Lothian.

item.title: Insolvency figures 'to stay high'
item.description: As many as 100,000 Scots will become insolvent in the next five years, a leading accountancy firm predicts.

item.title: Teenage death now murder inquiry
item.description: Police have said they are treating an attack in Omagh that led to the death of a County Monaghan teenager as murder.

item.title: Two released over police car bomb
item.description: Two men arrested by detectives investigating the attempted murder of a policeman after a bomb was placed under his car in Belfast are released unconditionally.

item.title: Oyster-style card rollout delays
item.description: Plans to allow passengers to use a Welsh version of the Oyster card across public transport face severe delays.

item.title: Council rejects break away plan
item.description: An attempt by Llanelli to break away from Carmarthenshire council amid claims it is being neglected is rejected by town councillors.

item.title: CAR rebels halt advance on Bangui
item.description: Seleka rebels in the Central African Republic say they are halting their advance on the capital, Bangui, as neighbouring countries deploy troops.

item.title: Uganda 'dismisses gay play case'
item.description: A court in Uganda throws out a case against UK theatre producer David Cecil, who was charged over a play about the condition of gay people, he tells the BBC.

item.title: Burma military 'targeting rebels'
item.description: Military aircraft have been targeting rebel areas in Burma's northern Kachin state over the last five days, video footage obtained by the BBC shows.

item.title: Delhi women march against rape
item.description: Thousands of women take part in a rally in the Indian capital, Delhi, to protest against the recent gang rape of a 23-year-old medical student.

item.title: Italy's Monti launches campaign
item.description: Italy's caretaker Prime Minister, Mario Monti, promises to cut labour taxes in an interview seen as the launch of his election campaign.

item.title: Paris apartment fire kills five
item.description: Two adults and three youngsters die in an apartment fire in Gennevilliers, a northern suburb of Paris.

item.title: Chavez 'conscious' says his deputy
item.description: Venezuela's President Hugo Chavez is conscious but in a "delicate and complex situation" after a cancer operation in Cuba, his deputy says.

item.title: Air strike 'kills 13 Farc rebels'
item.description: The Colombian Air Force says it has killed 13 Farc rebels in an attack on a camp in Antioquia province, as peace talks are due to resume in Cuba.

item.title: Deadly blasts hit Iraqi cities
item.description: At least 22 people have been killed - and many more injured - in a series of explosions across Iraq, officials say.

item.title: Egyptian TV satirist faces probe
item.description: Popular Egyptian television satirist Bassem Youssef is being investigated by prosecutors for allegedly insulting President Mohammed Morsi.

item.title: Sandy aid bill to get House vote
item.description: The US House will hold a vote on a $60bn (£37bn) aid package for areas hit by "superstorm" Sandy by 15 January, Speaker John Boehner says.

item.title: Obama praises 'fiscal cliff' deal
item.description: President Barack Obama hails a deal reached in the US Congress to raise taxes on wealthy people and delay spending cuts.

item.title: The year in pictures 2012
item.description: The pictures that made the headlines in 2012

item.title: Week in pictures: 22-28 December 2012
item.description: News photographs from around the world

item.title: Day in pictures: 28 December 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 28 December

item.title: The UK year in pictures 2012
item.description: A selection of the best pictures from 2012

item.title: Day in pictures: 27 December 2012
item.description: 24 hours of news photos: 27 December

item.title: In pictures: Snowstorm hits US
item.description: Snow storm in north-eastern US states

item.title: In pictures: Christmas celebrations
item.description: Images from around the world

item.title: In pictures: Stonehenge solstice
item.description: 5,000 people mark the winter solstice

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: Prime Minister David Cameron and Labour leader Ed Miliband have clashed over the government's record on poverty, during the last prime minister's question session of the year.

item.title: AUDIO: Delhi rape victim whispered 'I'm sorry'
item.description: The father of the 23-year-old Delhi rape victim has been speaking to the BBC about his daughter.

item.title: VIDEO: Friends search for missing teenager
item.description: A shoreline search is being carried out by police and friends of a missing teenager who jumped from a ferry into a river on New Year's Eve.

item.title: VIDEO: 60,000 dead in Syrian unrest
item.description: More than 60,000 people have been killed since Syria's uprising began in March 2011, the UN has said.

item.title: VIDEO: Pensioners restore WWII bomber
item.description: Two pensioners from Lincolnshire have restored a rare WWII Lancaster bomber and are hoping to get it flying again.

item.title: VIDEO: 'Grey pound' is box office gold
item.description: More films aimed at audiences aged over 60 are due to be released in 2013.

item.title: VIDEO: WPP's Sorrell reignites tax row
item.description: Sir Martin Sorrell, chief executive of global advertising group WPP, has said the amount of corporation tax companies pay is largely "a question of judgement".

item.title: VIDEO: Diet doctor urges intermittent fasting
item.description: A new diet book is suggesting that the best way to lose weight is to eat normally for five days a week, but to fast for two.

item.title: VIDEO: Seal filmed swimming in flooded field
item.description: Keen birdwatcher films a seal in a flooded field several miles from the nearest coastline.

item.title: Delhi rape victim's family: She was brave, full of life
item.description: Delhi gang rape victim's family speaks to the BBC

item.title: Audio slideshow: Exploring Africa
item.description: Uncovering bizarre new creatures in four-year African odyssey

item.title: BBC Sound of 2013: Angel Haze
item.description: Rapper Angel Haze on overcoming her troubled youth

item.title: 'Confusion' over how active we should be
item.description: The confusion over how active we should be

item.title: History's weirdest fad diets
item.description: Was this parasite-based diet history's weirdest eating fad?

item.title: Inside Nigeria's secret gay club
item.description: Fear inside one of Nigeria's few gay clubs

item.title: Alone at the seaside
item.description: Why do divorcees like to be beside the seaside?

item.title: Cliffhanger: Still hanging
item.description: US politicians cobble together messy budget compromise
